Adding DnD to the template:
```[ERROR] line 16: Blog Post templates cannot contain drag and drop areas. Template `templateType` must be one of [blog_listing, starter_landing_page, section, page]```
Should be available though: <https://community.HubSpot.com/t5/HubSpot-Ideas/Drag-amp-Drop-functionality-for-Blog-Posts/idi-p/408909/page/2#comments>
Yes I believe so. I assume it was installed when I ran the "hs init" command.
There's no change needed to enable this, `{{ content.post_body }}` will automatically allow you to drag and drop modules in it

Have you verified that you are using a valid SSL certificate, because HubSpot, from what I have read, requires the entire certificate chain (I am no expert on certificates). Try using <https://www.ssllabs.com/> to check your URL

Another option for you could be to try and set up the webhook trigger in a Workflow instead, here you get access to workflow log with a lot of information

I would recommend you use WorkFlows to test the webhook functionality instead of using apps. This is way easier and have better logs

But if you want to use an app you use the install URL found in your app settings and run it in the HubSpot env. where you want to install the app.

After you have approved installation your return URL will contain a code. You need to use this code in a post event to create the initial tokens for your app. You can follow this example
<https://legacydocs.HubSpot.com/docs/methods/oauth2/get-access-and-refresh-tokens>

You can use postman or other to create the post, and remember to set the correct body-data-format

<https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/api/working-with-oauth>
HubSpot made a rule last june that you need to request at least one refresh token before the app will actually install on an account

Hi everyone,
just a quick question: is it possible to turn a coded template into a dnd area?
Like, you have a coded template with several module_block modules in it and pages built with it having their content already been edited. I'd like to turn them into dnd areas so that our customer can add custom modules wherever they want, without losing the pages' current content.
Wrapping the entire HTML in dnd tags doesn't work because dnd areas don't accept module_block.
I really don't want to assume that the only way to achieve this is creating a new template with dnd area and inserting manually all the current content after being turned into several custom modules, for all pages...
Is there an easier way to accomplish that?

Take a look at how the boilerplate theme is set up with section includes <https://github.com/HubSpot/cms-theme-boilerplate>

What you described (I think?) is how the boilerplate theme is set up out of the gate, with dnd_modules added inside of drag and drop sections

You might be able to preserve module content by making sure the modules have the same names in the new and old templates? (ex. `{% module 'module_xyz' %}` -> `{% dnd_module 'module_xyz' %}`) I haven’t personally tried it, but it’d be worth a shot.

Hi all! Don't know where to post this but in need some help of triggering this error message to appear on the embedded HubSpot form. This is what i have so far and does not work with I enter a few numbers. I added a few keys to see what potentially could work but all failed(nothing appeared).Please & thank you!

You’ve basically got the gist of what I was suggesting. I can’t say I use the `module_block` syntax very often, but the module name/id *should* be serving the same purpose.

But yes, unfortunately, I think you’re right that there’s not going to be a good way around recreating the pages in the dnd editor. That’s what I’ve had to do in previous conversions.

That's unfortunate. Thank you for your suggestions.
By the way, just out of curiosity, you said that you don't use the module_block syntax that often, so I'm wondering what you usually use in coded templates to give customers the ability to edit content :slightly_smiling_face:

Modules added via the `{% module %}` tag can be edited via the page editor interface! To my understanding, the `{% module_block %}` tag just allows the developer to use a different syntax to define the default property values.
I see. Maybe it's because I'm used to insert a block of HTML as the default content, especially for rich text modules, like <h1>, <p> ecc., not just a simple inline text value.
